componenttext:
Good morning, ladies gentlemen welcome to the Travelers first quarter results for Travelers. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded on April 21, 2016.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Ms. Gabriella Nawi, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Nawi, you may now begin.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers discussion of our 2016 first quarter results. Hopefully, all of you have seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation we released earlier this morning. All of these materials can b
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers discussion of our 2016 first quarter results. Hopefully, all of you have seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation we released earlier this morning. All of these materials can be found on our website at www.travelers.com, under the Investor section.
Speaking today will be Alan Schnitzer, CEO; Jay Benet, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian MacLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Doreen Spadorcia, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Claim, Personal Insurance and Bond & Specialty Insurance.
They will discuss the financial results of our business in the current market environment. They will refer to the webcast presentation as they both are prepared remarks, and then we will take questions. In addition, Jay Fishman and other members of senior management team are in the room.
Before I turn it over to Alan, I would like to drive your attention to the net included at the end of the webcast. Our presentation today includes forward-looking statements. The company cautions investors that any forward-looking statements involves risk and uncertainties and is not a performance and actual results may differ materially from projected in the forward-looking statements due to a variety of factors. These factors are described in our earnings press release in our most recent 10-Q and 10-K filed with the SEC. We do not undertaking any obligation to update forward-looking statements.
Also in our remarks or response to questions, we may mention some non-deferential measures. Reconciliations are included in our recent earnings press release, financial supplement and other materials that are available on the Investor section of our website.
And now, Alan Schnitzer.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported first quarter operating income of $698 million or $2.33 per share, an operating return on equity of 12.5%. Especially in light of a relatively high lev
componenttext:
Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported first quarter operating income of $698 million or $2.33 per share, an operating return on equity of 12.5%. Especially in light of a relatively high level of catastrophe losses in the quarter, our underwriting results across the board remain strong, as reflected in our combined ratio of 92.3%. 
To put the weather in some context, our catastrophe losses were about $100 million after-tax higher in the quarter than they were last year and these are the highest first quarter cat losses we have since 2010.
The timing of catastrophes is, of course, unpredictable, but this level of weather volatility is certainly within our playbook. We're confident in our ability to model and manage our exposures and that the pricing appropriate for the risk.
In this case, it just so happens that by design we have a healthy market share in the Dallas-Fort Worth net reflex, where severe were concentrated. Doreen have more to say about the severity and about our claim analytics.
The real story this quarter is about our execution in the marketplace and across all of our businesses we couldn't be more pleased. In our commercial businesses, we continue to be successful in our efforts to maximize retentions on our best performing accounts and improve profitability on poor-performing business.
Retentions in the quarter were again at very high levels by historical standards and renewal premium change was positive. We believe this productions is also right on target given our review product returns, but as we explained before, we don't manage the business on an aggregate basis. We execute deliberately account by account or class by class, and you can see this on Slide 13 of the webcast, which displays a distribution of rate changes for a Middle Market accounts in the first quarter.
As you can see from slide, most accounts received a single-digit increase, and there were a number of accounts had a increase of greater than 5 or even 10%. So even now with the headline change just slightly negative, we continue to achieve rate gains in excess of loss trend on our poor-performing business. The real take away from this slide is that the aggregate number is simply an average of thousands of individual account actions. And that success is this business is not about the aggregate rate number, it's about taking the right action on each account and generating an appropriate return over time.
Our execution in the quarter also benefited from a commercial lines pricing environment that from our advantage point continues to be remarkably stable. The outlook that we provided this morning in our 10-Q for our BII and BSI segments suggest more of the same continued high levels of retention and broadly consistent underlying underwriting markets.
In terms of execution, we were just a successful in insurance business with strong retentions in higher pit counts in both agency auto and agency Homeowners.
Importantly, Quantum Auto 2.0 continues to meet our expectations on all fronts. The successful execution across all of our businesses resulted in consolidated net written premiums that were about 5% higher in the quarter than they were in the prior year. Both new business levels and historically high levels of retention, particularly, in the middle market business contributed significantly to the top line growth. The quality and brother for our products and services are extraordinary talent in the field and strength of the relationship that we have with our agent and broker partners put us in a great position to win.
In addition to that, we believed we benefited in the quarter both in terms of new and renewable businesses from the stability and consistency we provide in the marketplace compared to some of our competitors who're experiencing degrees of disruption.
Turning to capital management, because the reflection of the confident that we have in our business, today our Board of Directors declared an approximate 10% increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.67 per share, the 12 consecutive year of dividend increases, improving the compound annual growth rate of the dividend almost 10% over that time.
All in all, despite an active quarter from a catastrophe perspective, a great start to the year.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Jay Benet.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. I'll start by saying that we work with our first quarter results operating income of $698 million and operating return on equity of 12.5%, despite they're being lower than prior year quarter. As Page 4, the webcast indicates, the $129 millio
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. I'll start by saying that we work with our first quarter results operating income of $698 million and operating return on equity of 12.5%, despite they're being lower than prior year quarter. As Page 4, the webcast indicates, the $129 million decrease in operating income from last year's first quarter did not come about due to lower underlying underwriting results.
Our consolidated underlying combined ratios is 90% this quarter, 30 basis points better than the prior year quarter. Rather the decrease in operating income along with the decrease in operating ROE resulted from 2 items: cat losses that were $101 million higher on an after-tax basis than those in the first quarter of 2015, and as we anticipated the outlook section of our 2015 10-K, a $24 million after-tax reduction in fixed income net investment income that was driven by the continuing low interest rate environment.
Page 4 also provides an analysis as to how our reported results compared to analysts' estimates, as best we can tell, analysts' estimates for cat losses were significantly lower than what actually occurred, which more than accounts for the difference. Our net investment income was $439 million after-tax this quarter, which was $39 million lower than the prior year quarter. In addition to the lower fixed income returns, non-fixed income NII was down $15 million after-tax due to lower hedge fund returns that resulted from the more challenging capital market conditions in recent months.
Each of our business segments once again contributed to net favorable prior year reserved development, which totaled $180 million on a pre-tax basis. In Business and International Insurance, net favorable development of $93 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience in Workers' Comp excess coverages for accident years 2006 and prior; and general liability, primarily for excess coverages for accident years 2011 and 2013; and commercial auto for accident years 2010 and prior in our European and Canadian operations. In Bond & Specialty Insurance, net favorable development of $60 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience and surety for accident years 2012 through 2014; and in Personal Insurance, net favorable development of $27 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience in Homeowners and others for liability coverages for accident year 2014 and an auto for accident year 2014.
On a combined stat basis, for all of our U.S. subs, all accident years developed favorably other than the 2015 accident year, which is currently showing $65 million of unfavorable development due to a few large property losses that occurred late in 2015 and a decision we made to rebalance Personal Insurance reserves among various accident years.
In addition, other than commercial multiple all product lines either developed favorably or had to minimus unfavorable development this quarter. All CMP developed unfavorably by $35 million. There was offsetting favorable development in the property product line as Middle Market property losses that had been recorded in the property line at year-end 2015 with subsequently determined to be CMP related.
Operating cash flows of $850 million remained very strong, and we ended the quarter with holding company liquidity of over $1.7 billion. All of our capital ratios were at or better than their target levels. Net unrealized investment gains were approximately $2.7 million pre-tax or $1.8 billion after-tax, up from $2 billion and $1.3 million, respectively, at the beginning of the year, while book value per share of $82.65 and adjusted book value per share of $76.63, increased 4% and 2%, respectively, from the beginning of the year.
We continue to generate much more capital than we need to support our business, allowing us to return $790 million of excess capital to our shareholders this quarter. We paid dividends of $181 million and repurchased $609 million of our common shares this quarter, including $550 million under our publicly announced share repurchase program consistent with our ongoing capital management strategy and $59 million to partially offset shares issued under employee incentive plans, mostly to cover employee withholding taxes due upon investing any payout of performance and restricted stock awards. And now -- and as Alan said, the board raised our quarterly dividend from $0.61 to $0.67 per share.
So with that, let me turn the over to Brian.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. In Business and International Insurance, operating income was $476 million with a combined ratio of 94.8. The underlying combined ratio, which excludes the impact of the cats and prior year reserved development, was 93.3, up about 0.5 point c
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. In Business and International Insurance, operating income was $476 million with a combined ratio of 94.8. The underlying combined ratio, which excludes the impact of the cats and prior year reserved development, was 93.3, up about 0.5 point compared to the first quarter of 2015, reflecting a typical level of quarterly fluctuations within both the loss and expense ratios. This resulted in line with expectations and we continue to feel very good about our underlying results.
Net written premiums for the quarter were up 3% year-over-year with domestic business insurance premiums up about 5%, driven by the strong production results across all our businesses. In domestic business insurance, we remained pleased with the continued execution of our pricing strategy. Given the attractive returns that we're generating in this business, our focus continues to be on retention, and accordingly, we're very pleased that retention is at a historical high of 85% for the quarter.
Renewal premium change came in at 2.2 points, while renewal rate change was down slightly in the quarter and about flat overall. New business increased to $575 million reflecting strong results across all our businesses.
Turning to the individual businesses, beginning with Select, we achieved strong retention of 81% and renewal premium change of nearly 7%. Rate change was down about 1 point versus the fourth quarter of 2015, driven a large part by recently filed rate changes in Workers' Compensation. We generated new business of $103 million, up slightly year-over-year.
In Middle Market, retention reached a historic high of 88% with renewal premium changes of 1 point in-line with the fourth quarter of 2015. Importantly, retention of our best performing business was approximately 90%, while for are poor-performing accounts, we achieved rate gains in excess of loss trends.
New business of $321 million was up 8% year-over-year, doing large part to strong results in our construction business. In other business insurance, retention of 82% was up both year-over-year and compared to the fourth quarter of 2015. Renewal premium change of about a point was in line with recent quarters, while new business of $151 million was up 24% versus the prior year, driven by Marine, boiler and transportation lines of business.
So across domestic business insurance, we achieved strong retention and so increased level of new business opportunities in the marketplace. As Allen mention, our agents and brokers view us as a stable market with industry-leading products and services, which we believe had a favorable impact on both retention and new business, particularly, in this environment where several significant competitors are experiencing some degree of disruption.
Turning to International, net written premiums for the first quarter were down about 10% year-over-year, primarily, due to the adverse impact of foreign exchange rates. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, net written premiums were down about 4% driven by disciplined underwriting in the face of highly competitive market conditions in the property lines at 
Retention for the quarter was strong at 82%. Renewal premium change was slightly negative, but above recent quarters. And new business of $76 million was up more than 30% year-over-year, driven primarily by Optima, our new strategic personal lines auto product in Canada. This product was modeled after our U.S.-based Quantum Auto 2.0 product, and while we're still in the early days of the rollout we're encouraged by the response as we continue to see a significant increase in new business volume.
In summary, in the segment we achieved strong underlying underwriting and production results, a great start to 2016.
And with that, let me turn it over to Doreen.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Bond & Specialty Insurance started 2016 with a strong first quarter, and we remain exceptionally pleased with the financial returns in this segment. For the quarter, operating income was $144 million, up from
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Bond & Specialty Insurance started 2016 with a strong first quarter, and we remain exceptionally pleased with the financial returns in this segment. For the quarter, operating income was $144 million, up from the first quarter of 2015, due primarily to a higher level of net favorable prior year reserve development also improved underlying underwriting results.
The underlying combined ratio of 81.1% was almost 2 points better than the prior year, driven by 2 items: one, the favorable expense impact of certain customer-related intangible assets, which became fully amortized during the second quarter of 2015; and second, lower loss levels in certain management liability businesses.
Underlined returns in this segment were once again very strong and remain well within our target level. Results like this do not happen by accident. Insights provided by our industry expertise and analytics along with disciplined execution of long-term strategies, have positioned us to successfully navigate a rising economic challenges, the most recent being the disruption in the coal and broader energy sectors.
As for top line, we generated higher net written premiums for the quarter as compared to 2015, in both our Management Liability and Surety businesses. The increase Surety production reflected higher contract bond activity from midsized construction accounts. Across our Management Liability businesses, retention remain strong at 87%, new business premium was up more than 20% from the first quarter of 2015 and renewable premium change was up from recent quarters driven by the non-rate components of including slight increases in policy duration and insured exposures.
These results reflect the execution of our strategy to retain our best account and write more business in our return adequate product segments. In strong top and bottom line results with Bond & Specialty and we continue to feel great about this segment's performance.
I'll now turn to Personal Insurance. Operating income for the quarter was $139 million, down $113 million from the prior year quarter, due to $69 million in higher tax and $68 million in lower net favorable prior year reserve development. The segment's underlying combined ratio for the quarter was 86.1%, 1.4 points better than the 2015 quarter. This improvement was driven by a lower expense ratio, which was due in large part to higher premium volume. We continue to be pleased with production results and underlying financial returns in both agency auto and agency Homeowners and other.
Looking at agency auto, we once again generated strong topline results and the loss experience of Quantum Auto 2.0 continues to perform in line with expectations. The combined ratio of 95.2% for the quarter was 5 points higher than the prior year quarter, due primarily to higher cap and lower level of net favorable prior year reserve development.
The underlying combined ratio of 94% was up 1 point from last year, in line with our expectations for the quarter. As we discussed before, the significant levels of new business we in the last couple of years will result in a higher calendar year loss ratio in the early years and improve over time. Quantum Auto 2.0 is priced to our long-term target return and is maturing in line with our expectations. As for our overall view of loss trend's, blended and severity remains unchanged at around 3%.
Production result continue to be exceptional as the agency auto with net written premiums up 13% year-over-year driven by higher new business premium and strong retention. We continue to grow policy which increased 55,000 during the quarter.
Turning to Agency Homeowners and other, we generated a combined ratio of 90.4%, even including catastrophes of 16 points. When cats were higher this quarter, the underlying combined ratio of 76.2% improved more than 3 points from the prior year quarter, driven by favorable non-cap weather.
As you all know, weather will be volatile from period-to-period. As Alan mentioned, this quarter was particularly, impacted by severe hailstorm in the greater Dallas-Fort Worth area. Slide 20 one of the webcast is an extract from our which many of you will recognize from our Investor Day.
This view is Cat 21, the most substantial event in the quarter and shows you how much of it was impacted by 2 and even 3 each This demonstrates our proprietary capability to get real-time data about size and duration, as well as potentially impacted policies.
Using this information facilitates a more respective claim response and fits up in estimating losses.
Using these tools, as well as our on-site work in the area, we identified this as a significant event early on and we're somewhat surprised that how well the industry estimates were. As more information has become public, it would appear that industry estimates for this event will rise.
Notwithstanding the weather volatility, we remain very pleased with the underlying financial returns were generating in this business as we continue to execute our disciplined underwriting and pricing strategies.
As for production, in Agency Homeowners and other, we continue to make good progress in line with our expectations. New business premium was up more than 30% from the prior year quarter, retention remained strong at 85% and we had a 26,000 policies during the quarter. So even with the significant cash during the quarter, a great start to the year for Personal Insurance.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Gabby.

componenttext: Kai, this is Brian MacLean. I just chime in on the new business front. First of all, I'd emphasize that we haven't changed any of our return thresholds or target prising. componenttext: Understood. And then I guess, my follow-up than would be just for Jay Bennett on the investment income side. And it seems like a lot of the discussions around lower investment yields, but something us a little bit, is it looks like the average invested assets were down about a little more than 1% on the quarter? And it also look like there was -- in the 10-Q an illusion up $0.5 billion on that side is coming in the second quarter. So just trying to understand when nothing more than $25 million to $30 million quarterly drag, is that contemplating sort of a lower level of invested assets or should we think about that as all just being driven by your review of lower the investment rates?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Bennett. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the direct ac
componenttext: This is Jay Bennett. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the direct actions, settlement for asbestos that brought the average down a little bit. And as you rightly point out, we're expecting to make a final payment on the settlement when other parties finalize some of the remaining issues, which are we don't view as significant issues in the second quarter. We expect to make that payment in the second quarter, so that we have an impact as we. Something else for the average invested assets, some of our assets are denominated in foreign currency. So you do have some currency exchange taken place, where in affect the assets are still the same, just the currency adjusted value is a little lower, but those are the 2 primary things that asbestos payments that bring it down.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hope get a little bit more color on, if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what has talked about in the
componenttext: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hope get a little bit more color on, if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what has talked about in the industry is a little bit upside down, I mean, it's -- a little surprising the size of it. So I would appreciate any help you would give on what's you think is really causing that expansion?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there is certainly nothing different in our -- the return threshold that we're seeking that's dragging that, and it -- both increased levels of retention and
componenttext: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there is certainly nothing different in our -- the return threshold that we're seeking that's dragging that, and it -- both increased levels of retention and new business are contributing to it. I think, that's an important point. And we really start with, what I said in my opening remarks, we think it's a quality and breadth of our products and services, the talent we have in the field, the relationships we have with our producers, all of that always puts us in a great position to win. And on top of that this quarter, as both Brian and I noted, there was some disruption in the marketplace and given our stability out there, we do think we benefit from that. It's hard probably impossible for any of this or to put a final point on the allocation of dollars, to one cause or another, but we do think all of those things coming together resulted in the new business levels.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, I guess, for Doreen, I saw a earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners' policy. I'm just curious any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using
componenttext: All right. And then, I guess, for Doreen, I saw a earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners' policy. I'm just curious any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using technology into personal lines be at pricing, be it UBI, et cetera?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know, we have drive where we do offer a discount, it's a mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and perhap
componenttext: Yes. We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know, we have drive where we do offer a discount, it's a mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and perhaps moving beyond mileage. So that's obviously, on the list. Second, we did rollout in a couple of pilot states, for use -- for individuals, when they're using their car for Uber, and what it really does is it covers what period and match, then the coverage it's clear that there isn't any personal insurance coverage. And then, this discount for connected homes. And if you think about it, similar to what we would do for someone who has an alarm or something of that sort, but we do have both of our claims, both of our homes of that claim connected home, so we can study how the data comes in. We can study what that changes about the underwriting process and the claim process. And we're also the -- a member of which has a very sophisticated connected home in Kentucky, and we're the only insurer on that home board looking for all the applications in the connected space. So that's just a little of what we've got going on.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first question for Doreen, just wanted to follow-up on the personal auto side. I believe the frequency was up 3% this quarter for personal auto. Curious as to what it was last year? And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so f
componenttext: So the first question for Doreen, just wanted to follow-up on the personal auto side. I believe the frequency was up 3% this quarter for personal auto. Curious as to what it was last year? And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so far in the Northeast and the first quarter on a frequency?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to give you really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 for frequency and 2.5 for severity. And that's been something that simply ha
componenttext: I'm going to give you really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 for frequency and 2.5 for severity. And that's been something that simply have baked into our results for 2 to 3 years at this point. So let me just go back a little bit on frequency because I know we've talked a lot about it. We talked a lot about it at We know these others have commented on frequency in the industry. Some have commented that they are seeing higher frequency, some have not commented at all. So we don't feel like it's the thing that's ripping through the industry. It's affecting very specific companies. And the most important thing for us is where you're starting from. What assumptions have you made. So we have not assumed frequency for a number of years that's been 0.5. The other thing talked about last quarter, so I apologize if it is repetitive, but in '14, there were some observations that frequency was dropping. We analyzed that very carefully and really didn't think that it was systemic or sustainable. And so at that point, while we recognize the financial impact of that lower frequency for '14, we went into '15 assuming that trend was going to go back to where it was and it did. And so the half a point remains unchanged, the trend remains unchanged, and it really goes back where we start from.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. It seems that the growth was fostered in middle market and other Business Insurance where pricing is slightly weaker than the Select accoun
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. It seems that the growth was fostered in middle market and other Business Insurance where pricing is slightly weaker than the Select accounts. So was that just a coincidence or just curious as to what's happening between those segments?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ye, I think, this is -- so this is Brian. I think, in middle market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so
componenttext: Ye, I think, this is -- so this is Brian. I think, in middle market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so I think part of it is the activity we've had, I think, it's also linked to. And again, as Alan said, you can't draw prefect connections here, but there is disruption in the marketplace amongst some significant competitors. And I think our strong position with agents and brokers and the breadth of product that we have in capabilities have really helped us there. so Takes I think we're very comfortable. As I also said, we're obsessing over the quality. So we're looking at all of those deals. In the other business insurance, well, there is some specific opportunities, we've got a transportation company Insurance, that does the smaller end of trucking business, so not the large fleets, primarily. They've had some need opportunities. There's been some opportunity in the Marine and business. Again, some result of some actions that other carriers have taken. So I think all of those things have added up to it. And it's not, I think, I guess, the main point, it's not tied directly to pricing and price change opportunity.

componenttext: I think, you're asking the question why is the effective tax rate lower this quarter than it had been in the prior year quarter. componenttextpreview: Following up on the Business Insurance underlying margin, is it fair to say that stable this year most because there was higher non-cap weather in 2015, but then if you look out going forward, it would probably deteriorate because prices are below loss --
componenttext: Following up on the Business Insurance underlying margin, is it fair to say that stable this year most because there was higher non-cap weather in 2015, but then if you look out going forward, it would probably deteriorate because prices are below loss -- is that a fair assumption or am I off?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It wasn't so much with an Business Insurance as it was a higher volume of large losses in the last three quarters of last year. And -- one of the reasons that we gave out 3 or 4 quarters is just perspective view on that gets unreliable. So I don't kn
componenttext: Yes. It wasn't so much with an Business Insurance as it was a higher volume of large losses in the last three quarters of last year. And -- one of the reasons that we gave out 3 or 4 quarters is just perspective view on that gets unreliable. So I don't know, but what I would point you to is the way we've been able to manage intense across all 3 business segments over a longer of time throughout a bunch of different conditions. And so you look at what Doreen and Greg and Michael had done in Personal Insurance by taking some difficult actions and repositioning that business and rolling out a new product. You look it would come -- in Bond & Specialty in a bunch of credit-sensitive businesses to a very difficult period, and a financial crisis. Think of a lot of done business insurance going back to 2010, when you look at -- we went back down and look at the outlook for returns and realized that we had to do some things differently. So your perspective that it might fall off beyond where we're giving guidance for, suggest purely current course and speed and I would say that their current courses with because we like where it because we get to a point in time a road map for returns and 2 different things. headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers' discussion of our 2016 first quarter results. Hopefully, all of you had seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation released earlier this morning. All of these materials can be f
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers' discussion of our 2016 first quarter results. Hopefully, all of you had seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation released earlier this morning. All of these materials can be found on our website at www.travelers.com, under the Investors section.
Speaking today will be Alan Schnitzer, CEO; Jay Benet, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; Brian MacLean, President and Chief Operating Officer; and Doreen Spadorcia, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Claim, Personal Insurance and Bond & Specialty Insurance. They will discuss the financial results of our business and the current market environment. They will refer to the webcast presentation as they go through prepared remarks, and then we will take questions. In addition, Jay Fishman and other members of senior management team are in the room.
Before I turn it over to Alan, I'd like to draw your attention to the explanatory note included at the end of the webcast. Our presentation today includes forward-looking statements. The company cautions investors that any forward-looking statement involves risk and uncertainties and is not a guarantee of future performance. Actual results may differ materially from these projected in the forward-looking statements due to a variety of factors. These factors are described in our earnings press release and in our most recent 10-Q and 10-K filed with the SEC. We do not undertake any obligation to update forward-looking statements.
Also, in our remarks or responses to questions, we may mention some non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations are included in our recent earnings press release, financial supplement and other materials that are available on the Investors section on our website.
And now Alan Schnitzer.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported first quarter operating income of $698 million or $2.33 per share and operating return on equity of 12.5%. Especially in light of a relatively high lev
componenttext:
Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported first quarter operating income of $698 million or $2.33 per share and operating return on equity of 12.5%. Especially in light of a relatively high level of catastrophe losses in the quarter, our underwriting results across the board remained strong, as reflected in our combined ratio of 92.3%. 
To put the weather in some context, our catastrophe losses were about $100 million, after tax, higher in the quarter than they were last year, and these are the highest first quarter cat losses we've had since 2010. The timing of catastrophes is, of course, unpredictable, but this level of weather volatility is certainly within our playbook. We're confident in our ability to model and manage our exposures and that we're pricing appropriately for the risk.
In this case, it just so happens that by design, we have a healthy market share in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex, where severe hailstorms were concentrated. Doreen will have more to say about the severity and about our claim analytics.
The real story this quarter is about our execution in the marketplace, and across all our businesses, we couldn't be more pleased. In our commercial businesses, we continue to be successful in our efforts to maximize retentions on our best-performing accounts and improve profitability on poor-performing business. Retentions in the quarter were again at very high levels by historical standards, and renewal premium change was positive. We believe these production results are right on target given our view of product returns, but as we've explained before, we don't manage the business on an aggregate basis. We execute deliberately account by account or class by class, and you can see this on Slide 13 of the webcast, which displays the distribution of rate changes for our Middle Market accounts in the first quarter.
As you can see from the slide, most accounts received a single-digit rate increase, and there were a number of accounts that had a rate increase of greater than 5% or even 10%. So even now with the headline pure rate change just slightly negative, we continue to achieve rate gains in excess of loss trend on our poor-performing business. The real takeaway from this slide is that the aggregate rate number is simply an average of thousands of individual account actions and that success in this business is not about the aggregate rate number. It's about taking the right action on each account and generating an appropriate return over time.
Our execution in the quarter also benefited from a commercial lines pricing environment that, from our vantage point, continues to be remarkably stable. The outlook that we provided this morning in our 10-Q for our BII and BSI segments suggest more of the same: continued high levels of retention and broadly consistent underlying underwriting margins.
In terms of execution, we were just as successful in our Personal Insurance business, with strong retentions and higher PIF counts in both the Agency Auto and Agency Homeowners. Importantly, Quantum Auto 2.0 continues to meet our expectations on all fronts. The successful execution across all our businesses resulted in consolidated net written premiums that were about 5% higher in the quarter than they were in the prior year. Both new business levels and historically high levels of retention, particularly in our Middle Market business, contributed significantly to the top line growth. 
The quality and breadth of our products and services, our extraordinary talent in the field and the strength of the relationships that we have with our agent and broker partners put us in a great position to win. In addition to that, we believe that we benefited in the quarter, both in terms of new and renewal business, from the stability and consistency we provide in the marketplace compared to some of our competitors who are experiencing varying degrees of disruption.
Turning to capital management. As a reflection of the confidence that we have in our business, today, our Board of Directors declared an approximately 10% increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.67 per share, the 12th consecutive year of dividend increases and bringing the compound annual growth rate of the dividend to almost 10% over that time.
All in all, despite an active quarter from a catastrophe perspective, a great start to the year.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Jay Benet.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. I'll start by saying that we were pleased with our first quarter results, operating income of $698 million and operating return on equity of 12.5%, despite their being lower than the prior year quarter. As Page 4 of the webcast indicates,
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. I'll start by saying that we were pleased with our first quarter results, operating income of $698 million and operating return on equity of 12.5%, despite their being lower than the prior year quarter. 
As Page 4 of the webcast indicates, the $129 million decrease in operating income from last year's first quarter did not come about due to lower underlying underwriting results. Our consolidated underlying combined ratio is 90% this quarter, 30 basis points better than the prior year quarter. Rather, the decrease in operating income, along with the decrease in operating ROE, resulted from 2 items: cat losses that were $101 million higher on an after-tax basis than those in the first quarter of 2015; and as we anticipated in the outlook section of our 2015 10-K, a $24 million after-tax reduction in fixed income net investment income that was driven by the continuing low interest rate environment.
Page 4 also provides an analysis as to how our reported results compared to analysts' estimates. As best we can tell, analysts' estimates for cat losses were significantly lower than what actually occurred, which more than accounts for the difference. Our net investment income was $439 million after tax this quarter, which was $39 million lower than the prior year quarter. In addition to the lower fixed income returns, non-fixed income NII was down $15 million after tax due to lower hedge fund returns that resulted from the more challenging capital market conditions in recent months.
Each of our business segments once again contributed to net favorable prior year reserve development, which totaled $180 million on a pre-tax basis. In Business and International Insurance, net favorable development of $93 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience in workers' comp excess coverages for accident years 2006 and prior; in general liability, primarily for excess coverages for accident years 2011 and 2013; in commercial auto for accident years 2010 and prior; and in our European and Canadian operations. In Bond & Specialty Insurance, net favorable development of $60 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience in surety for accident years 2012 through 2014. And in Personal Insurance, net favorable development of $27 million resulted from better-than-expected loss experience in Homeowners & Other for liability coverages for accident year 2014 and in Auto for accident year 2014.
On a combined stat basis, for all of our U.S. subs, all accident years developed favorably other than the 2015 accident year, which is currently showing $65 million of unfavorable development due to a few large property losses that occurred late in 2015 and a decision we made to rebalance Personal Insurance reserves among various accident years.  In addition, other than commercial multi-peril, all product lines either developed favorably or had de minimis unfavorable development this quarter. While CMP developed unfavorably by $35 million, there was offsetting favorable development in the property product line as Middle Market property losses that had been recorded in the property line at year-end 2015 were subsequently determined to be CMP-related.
Operating cash flows of $850 million remained very strong, and we ended the quarter with holding company liquidity of over $1.7 billion. All of our capital ratios were at or better than their target levels. Net unrealized investment gains were approximately $2.7 billion pretax or $1.8 billion after tax, up from $2 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, at the beginning of the year. While book value per share of $82.65 and adjusted book value per share of $76.63 increased 4% and 2%, respectively, from the beginning of the year.
We continue to generate much more capital than we need to support our businesses, allowing us to return $790 million of excess capital to our shareholders this quarter. We paid dividends of $181 million and repurchased $609 million of our common shares this quarter, including $550 million under our publicly announced share repurchase program, consistent with our ongoing capital management strategy, and $59 million to partially offset shares issued under employee incentive plans, mostly to cover employee withholding taxes due upon the vesting and payout of performance and restricted stock awards. And as Alan said, the board raised our quarterly dividend from $0.61 to $0.67 per share.
So with that, let me turn the mic over to Brian.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. In Business and International Insurance, operating income was $476 million with a combined ratio of 94.8%. The underlying combined ratio, which excludes the impact of cats and prior year reserve development, was 93.3%, up about 0.5 point comp
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. In Business and International Insurance, operating income was $476 million with a combined ratio of 94.8%. The underlying combined ratio, which excludes the impact of cats and prior year reserve development, was 93.3%, up about 0.5 point compared to the first quarter of 2015, reflecting a typical level of quarterly fluctuations within both the loss and expense ratios. This result is in line with our expectations, and we continue to feel very good about our underlying results.
Net written premiums for the quarter were up 3% year-over-year, with domestic business insurance premiums up about 5%, driven by the strong production results across all our businesses. In domestic business insurance, we remain pleased with the continued execution of our pricing strategy. Given the attractive returns that we are generating in this business, our focus continues to be on retention, and accordingly, we're very pleased that retention is at a historical high of 85% for the quarter. Renewal premium change came in at 2.2 points, while renewal rate change was down slightly in the quarter and about flat overall. New business increased to $575 million, reflecting strong results across all our businesses.
Turning to the individual businesses, beginning with Select. We achieved strong retention of 81% and renewal premium change of nearly 7%. Rate change was down about 1 point versus the fourth quarter of 2015, driven in large part by recently filed rate changes in workers' compensation. We generated new business of $103 million, up slightly year-over-year.
In Middle Market, retention reached a historic high of 88%, with renewal premium change of 1 point, in line with the fourth quarter of 2015. Importantly, retention of our best-performing business was approximately 90%, while for our poor-performing accounts, we achieved rate gains in excess of loss trend.
New business of $321 million was up 8% year-over-year, due in large part to strong results in our construction business. In Other Business Insurance, retention of 82% was up both year-over-year and compared to the fourth quarter of 2015. Renewal premium change of about 1 point was in line with recent quarters, while new business of $151 million was up 24% versus the prior year, driven by inland marine, boiler and transportation lines of business.
So across domestic business insurance, we achieved strong retention and saw an increased level of new business opportunities in the marketplace. As Alan mentioned, our agents and brokers view us as a stable market with industry-leading products and services, which we believe had a favorable impact on both retention and new business, particularly in this environment where several significant competitors are experiencing some degree of disruption.
Turning to International. Net written premiums for the first quarter were down about 10% year-over-year primarily due to the adverse impact of foreign exchange rates. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, net written premiums were down about 4%, driven by disciplined underwriting in the face of highly competitive market conditions in the property lines at Lloyd's.
Retention for the quarter was strong at 82%. Renewal premium change was slightly negative but above recent quarters. And new business of $76 million was up more than 30% year-over-year, driven primarily by Optima, our new strategic personal lines auto product in Canada. This product was modeled after our U.S.-based Quantum Auto 2.0 product, and while we're still in the early days of the rollout, we're encouraged by the response as we continue to see a significant increase in new business volume. In summary, in the segment, we achieved strong underlying underwriting and production results, a great start to 2016.
And with that, let me turn it over to Doreen.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Bond & Specialty Insurance started 2016 with a strong first quarter, and we remain exceptionally pleased with the financial returns in this segment. For the quarter, operating income was $144 million, up from
componenttext:
Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. Bond & Specialty Insurance started 2016 with a strong first quarter, and we remain exceptionally pleased with the financial returns in this segment. For the quarter, operating income was $144 million, up from the first quarter of 2015 due primarily to a higher level of net favorable prior year reserve development but also improved underlying underwriting results.
The underlying combined ratio of 81.1% was almost 2 points better than the prior year, driven by 2 items: one, the favorable expense impact of certain customer-related intangible assets, which became fully amortized during second quarter of 2015; and second, lower loss levels in certain Management Liability businesses.
Underlying returns in this segment were once again very strong and remain well within our target level. Results like these do not happen by accident. Insights provided by our deep industry expertise and analytics, along with disciplined execution of long-term strategies, have positioned us to successfully navigate rising economic challenges, the most recent being the disruption in the coal and broader energy sectors.
As for top line, we generated higher net written premiums for the quarter as compared to 2015 in both our Management Liability and Surety businesses. The increased Surety production reflected higher contract bond activity from midsize construction accounts. Across our Management Liability businesses, retention remains strong at 87%. New business premium was up more than 20% from the first quarter of 2015. And renewal premium change was up from recent quarters, driven by the non-rate components of RPC, including slight increases in average policy duration and in surety exposures.
These results reflect the execution of our strategy to retain our best accounts and write more business in our return-adequate product segments. In sum, strong top and bottom line results for Bond & Specialty, and we continue to feel great about this segment's performance.
I'll now turn to Personal Insurance. Operating income for the quarter was $139 million, down $113 million from the prior year quarter due to $69 million in higher cats and $68 million in lower net favorable prior year reserve development. The segment's underlying combined ratio for the quarter was 86.1%, 1.4 points better than the 2015 quarter. This improvement was driven by a lower expense ratio, which was due in large part to higher premium volume. We continue to be pleased with production results and underlying financial returns in both Agency Auto and Agency Homeowners & Other.
Looking at Agency Auto, we once again generated strong top line results, and the loss experience of Quantum Auto 2.0 continues to perform in line with expectations. The combined ratio of 95.2% for the quarter was 5 points higher than the prior year quarter due primarily to higher cats and a lower level of net favorable prior year reserve development.
The underlying combined ratio of 94% was up 1 point from last year, in line with our expectations for the quarter. As we've discussed before, the significant levels of new business we've added in the last couple of years will result in a higher calendar year loss ratio in the early years and improve over time. Quantum Auto 2.0 is priced to our long-term target return and is maturing in line with our expectation. As for our overall view of loss trend, blended frequency and severity remains unchanged at around 3%.
Production results continue to be exceptional at Agency Auto, with net written premiums up 13% year-over-year, driven by higher new business premium and strong retention. We continue to grow policies in force, which increased 55,000 during the quarter.
Turning to Agency Homeowners & Other. We generated a combined ratio of 90.4%, even including catastrophes of 16 points. While cats were higher this quarter, the underlying combined ratio of 76.2% improved more than 3 points from the prior year quarter, driven by favorable non-cat weather.  As you all know, weather will be volatile from period to period. As Alan mentioned, this quarter was particularly impacted by severe hailstorms in the greater Dallas-Fort Worth area. Slide 21 of the webcast is an extract from our hail dashboard, which many of you will recognize from our Investor Day.
This view is CAT 21, the most substantial event in the quarter, and shows you how much of the area was impacted by 2- and even 3-inch hail. This demonstrates our proprietary capability to get near real-time data about hail size and duration as well as potentially impacted policies. Using this information facilitates a more effective claim response and assists us in estimating losses.
Using these tools, as well as our on-site work in the area, we identified this as a significant event early on, and we're somewhat surprised at how low the industry estimates were. As more information has become public, it would appear that industry estimates for this event will rise.
Notwithstanding the weather volatility, we remain very pleased with the underlying financial returns we're generating in this business as we continue to execute our disciplined underwriting and pricing strategies.
As for production, in Agency Homeowners & Other, we continue to make good progress, in line with our expectations. New business premium was up more than 30% from the prior year quarter. Retention remained strong at 85%, and we added 26,000 policies during the quarter. So even with the significant cats during the quarter, a great start to the year for Personal Insurance.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Gabby.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question on catastrophe in the quarter, the $380 million, almost 1/3 of your sort of normalized annual budget of $1 billion. So does this surprise you? And there were talk about heightened activity in hailstorms. Does it have implication for your
componenttext: My first question on catastrophe in the quarter, the $380 million, almost 1/3 of your sort of normalized annual budget of $1 billion. So does this surprise you? And there were talk about heightened activity in hailstorms. Does it have implication for your pricing as well as your market exposure?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Alan. Let me start, and I'll see if others want to fill in. As I said in my opening remarks, the timing of catastrophes are always surprising to us, but there's nothing about the level of losses in that storm that are particularly surprising. It's in
componenttext: It's Alan. Let me start, and I'll see if others want to fill in. As I said in my opening remarks, the timing of catastrophes are always surprising to us, but there's nothing about the level of losses in that storm that are particularly surprising. It's in our playbook, and we do feel like our risk selection in pricing is spot-on. So nothing about this event that causes us to rethink anything. And if it had been a couple of weeks later in the second quarter, where we typically expect more frequency of severe storms, we wouldn't really find anything about it. So timing off by maybe a couple of weeks, but nothing about it that we find surprising.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up question is on BI pricing. It looks like continued downward trends. I just wonder what give you confidence to maintain the good level of core margin or underlying margin given the downward pricing trend. As well as now you have a higher
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up question is on BI pricing. It looks like continued downward trends. I just wonder what give you confidence to maintain the good level of core margin or underlying margin given the downward pricing trend. As well as now you have a higher level of new business, how do you make sure the underwriting of this or that increase -- your initial [indiscernible]?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kai, it's -- if you look at the gradual slope of that pricing trend, yes, pricing is going down, but it's very, very gradual, and it's consistent with our product returns. And this is why we wanted to put in Slide 13 that really shows you the redistributi
componenttext: Kai, it's -- if you look at the gradual slope of that pricing trend, yes, pricing is going down, but it's very, very gradual, and it's consistent with our product returns. And this is why we wanted to put in Slide 13 that really shows you the redistribution. We continue to look at the execution on a granular basis, and we're very comfortable with the way that we're pricing relative to the returns that we expect that we're getting on these products.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Kai, this is Brian MacLean. I'd just chime in on the new business front. First of all, I'd emphasize that we haven't changed any of our return thresholds or target pricing. And if we're obsessing about one thing in the business today, it's the qu
componenttext: Yes. And Kai, this is Brian MacLean. I'd just chime in on the new business front. First of all, I'd emphasize that we haven't changed any of our return thresholds or target pricing. And if we're obsessing about one thing in the business today, it's the quality of the new business that we're taking in, and we remain very comfortable that it's in customer segments, products and industries that we really think we understand, so we feel very good about it.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ryan Tunis from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ryan Tunis from Crdit Suisse.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, I think, is for Doreen. Just looking at margins, I guess, in Agency Auto, looks like the accident year loss ratio deteriorated by a little more than 1.5 points. And it sounded like you're still attributing that mostly to just elevated n
componenttext: My first question, I think, is for Doreen. Just looking at margins, I guess, in Agency Auto, looks like the accident year loss ratio deteriorated by a little more than 1.5 points. And it sounded like you're still attributing that mostly to just elevated new business or the impact of new business. I'm just wondering if that's the type of margin drag we should expect for the remainder of the year from the pressure from new business or if there's anything else, at least in the short term, that maybe drove up that accident year loss ratio.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about that for a minute. It is really attributable, and I would say solely -- obviously, there's always a few things bouncing around, but driven by the volume of new business. What we build into our modeling curves is the maturity of the book
componenttext: Let me talk about that for a minute. It is really attributable, and I would say solely -- obviously, there's always a few things bouncing around, but driven by the volume of new business. What we build into our modeling curves is the maturity of the book of business. And so what you'll see over time is each cohort will begin to produce what our long-term returns are. So it is due to the level of new business.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then I guess my follow-up then would just be for Jay Benet on the investment income side. And it seems like a lot of the discussions around lower investment yields, but something  [indiscernible] to us a little bit. It looks like the
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then I guess my follow-up then would just be for Jay Benet on the investment income side. And it seems like a lot of the discussions around lower investment yields, but something  [indiscernible] to us a little bit. It looks like the average invested assets were down about a little more than 1% on the quarter. And it also looked like there was, in the 10-Q, an allusion to a $0.5 billion payment on the asbestos side that's coming in the second quarter. So just trying to understand, when you think about that $25 million to $30 million quarterly drag, is that contemplating sort of a lower level of invested assets? Or should we think about that as all just being driven by your view of lower investment rates?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Benet. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the Direct Acti
componenttext: This is Jay Benet. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the Direct Action's settlement for asbestos that brought the average down a little bit. And as you rightly point out, we're expecting to make a final payment on the PPG settlement when other parties finalize some of the remaining issues, which are -- we don't view as significant issues, in the second quarter. We expect to make that payment in the second quarter, so that will have an impact as well. Something else that affects the average invested assets, some of our assets are denominated in foreign currency. So you do have some currency exchange taking place, where, in effect, the assets are still the same, just the currency-adjusted value is a little lower. But those are the 2 primary things, the 2 asbestos payments, that bring it down.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Charles Sebaski from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Charles Sebaski from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hoping to just get a little bit more color on -- if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what is talked ab
componenttext: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hoping to just get a little bit more color on -- if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what is talked about in the industry is a little bit upside down. I mean, it's a little surprising, the size of it. So I would appreciate any help you could give on what you think is really causing that expansion.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there's certainly nothing different in our -- the return thresholds that we're seeking that's dragging that. And both increased levels of retention and new b
componenttext: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there's certainly nothing different in our -- the return thresholds that we're seeking that's dragging that. And both increased levels of retention and new business are contributing to it. I think that's an important point. And we really start with what I said in my opening remarks. We think it's the quality and breadth of our products and services, the talent we have in the field, the relationships we have with our producers. All that always puts us in a great position to win. And on top of that, this quarter, as both Brian and I noted, there was some disruption in the marketplace, and given our stability out there, we do think we benefit from that. It's hard, probably impossible, for any of this to try to put a final point on the allocation of dollars to one cause or another, but we do think all those things coming together resulted in our new business levels.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then I guess for Doreen, I saw earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners policies. I'm just curious, any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using te
componenttext: All right. And then I guess for Doreen, I saw earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners policies. I'm just curious, any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using technology into personal lines, be it pricing, be it UBI, et cetera?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know we have IntelliDrive, where we do offer a discount. It's mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and, perha
componenttext: We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know we have IntelliDrive, where we do offer a discount. It's mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and, perhaps, moving beyond mileage. So that's obviously on the list. Second, we did roll out in a couple of pilot states for use -- for individuals, when they're using their car for Uber. And what it really does is it covers what's called the trolling period until there's a match. Then the coverage is clear that there isn't any personal insurance coverage. And then this discount for connected homes. And if you think about it, similar to what we would do for someone who has an alarm or something of that sort, but we do have both of our claims -- both of our homes of that Claim U are connected homes, so we can study how the data comes in. We can study what that changes about the underwriting process and the claim process. And we're also a member of CNET [ph], which has a very sophisticated connected home in Kentucky, and we're the only insurer on that  CNET [ph] home board looking for all the applications in the connected space. So that's just a little of what we've got going on.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question for Doreen. Just wanted to follow up on the Personal Auto side. I believe you said frequency was up 3% this quarter for Personal Auto. Curious as to what it was last year. And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so
componenttext: The first question for Doreen. Just wanted to follow up on the Personal Auto side. I believe you said frequency was up 3% this quarter for Personal Auto. Curious as to what it was last year. And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so far in the Northeast in the first quarter on frequency?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to give you a really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 point for frequency and 2.5 for severity. And that's been something that w
componenttext: I'm going to give you a really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 point for frequency and 2.5 for severity. And that's been something that we'd basically had baked into our results for 2 to 3 years at this point. So let me just go back a little bit on frequency because I know we've talked a lot about it. We talked a lot about it at  [indiscernible]. We know that others have commented on frequency in the industry. Some have commented that they're seeing higher frequency. Some have not commented at all. So we don't feel like it's the thing that's just ripping through the industry. It's affecting very specific companies. And the most important thing for us is where you're starting from, what assumptions have you made. So we have not assumed flat frequency. For a number of years, it's been 0.5 point. The other thing I'll -- and we may have talked about this last quarter, so I apologize if it's repetitive. But in '14, there were some observations that frequency was dropping. We analyzed that very, very carefully and really didn't think it was systemic or sustainable. And so at that point, while we recognize the financial impact of that lower frequency for '14, we went into '15 assuming that trend was going to go back to where it was, and it did. And so the 0.5 point remains unchanged. The trend remains unchanged, and it really goes back to where you start from.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. And it seems that the growth was faster in Middle Market and Other Business Insurance, where pricing is maybe slightly weaker than the Sele
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. And it seems that the growth was faster in Middle Market and Other Business Insurance, where pricing is maybe slightly weaker than the Select accounts. So was that just a coincidence? Or just curious as to what's happening between those segments.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think this is -- so this is Brian. I think in Middle Market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so I
componenttext: Yes. I think this is -- so this is Brian. I think in Middle Market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so I think part of it is the activity we've had. I think it's also linked to -- and again, as Alan said, you can't draw prefect connections here, but there is disruption in the marketplace amongst some significant competitors. And I think our strong position with agents and brokers and the breadth of products that we have and capabilities have really helped us there. So I think we're very comfortable. As I also said, we're obsessing over the quality, so we're looking at all of those deals. In the Other Business Insurance, well, there are some specific opportunities. We've got a transportation company, Northland Insurance, that does the smaller end of the trucking business, so not the large fleets primarily. They've had some neat opportunities. There's been some opportunity in the inland marine and boiler business, again, somewhat a result of some actions that other carriers have taken. So I think all of those things have added up to it. And it's not -- I think -- I guess the main point: it's not tied directly to pricing and price change opportunity.

componenttext: Sure, Jay. It's Alan. When we talk about underlying underwriting margin in the outlook, what we're really talking about are dollars, not the combined ratio. And you could even look at that as opposite sides of the coin, but we, for instance, would consider volume in there as well. But we've got the outlook being broadly consistent, and obviously, we think about that as margin of something around the prior year period. But in that outlook, earned margin is a little bit negative, and we've got an expectation for large losses improving and volume also improving, and those 2 things adding give us an outlook of probably consistent.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I see. All right. And then my follow-up question is -- clearly, we had elevated first quarter catastrophe losses. Given all the destruction in Houston from the floods, if you can give us your perspective on that. And I know flooding isn't typically covered for things like Homeowners, but it would impact comprehensive auto or maybe some commercial property insurance. If you could help us out there.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jay, we're not going to preannounce second quarter results. I would say we're early in the quarter, and we typically expect the typical spring storms in the second quarter. So again, from a human perspective -- human side of the news is it's terrible
componenttext: Yes, Jay, we're not going to preannounce second quarter results. I would say we're early in the quarter, and we typically expect the typical spring storms in the second quarter. So again, from a human perspective -- human side of the news is it's terrible, but there's -- nothing about this that strikes us as particularly unusual there, bad second quarter storms.

componenttext: Doreen, just a follow-up on Ryan's question on Personal Auto. componenttext: And sorry, Mike, just to draw your attention to it. This is Gabby. headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you're asking the question why is the effective tax rate lower this quarter than it had been in the prior year quarter. And the effect of tax rate is always going be driven by the mix of tax-exempt income and fully taxable income. So what you
componenttext: Yes, I think you're asking the question why is the effective tax rate lower this quarter than it had been in the prior year quarter. And the effect of tax rate is always going be driven by the mix of tax-exempt income and fully taxable income. So what you're seeing here is the taxable income -- fully taxable income as a proportion of the total getting a little less because of the cat activity primarily. The change in the non-fully taxable income, the tax-exempt income, was pretty de minimis. So if you did a math on that, you'll see that's the effect on the effective tax rate.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Is there a similar new business effect for -- on the commercial lines side where the seasoning causes an increase in the accident year?
