componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ryan Tunis from Crdit Suisse.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, I think, is for Doreen. Just looking at margins, I guess, in Agency Auto, looks like the accident year loss ratio deteriorated by a little more than 1.5 points. And it sounded like you're still attributing that mostly to just elevated n
componenttext: My first question, I think, is for Doreen. Just looking at margins, I guess, in Agency Auto, looks like the accident year loss ratio deteriorated by a little more than 1.5 points. And it sounded like you're still attributing that mostly to just elevated new business -- or the impact of new business. I'm just wondering if that's the type of margin drag we should expect for the remainder of the year from the pressure from new business or if there's anything else, at least in the short term, that maybe drove up that accident year loss ratio.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about that for a minute. It is really attributable, and I would say solely -- obviously, there's always a few things bouncing around, but driven by the volume of new business. What we build into our modeling curves is the maturity of the book
componenttext: Let me talk about that for a minute. It is really attributable, and I would say solely -- obviously, there's always a few things bouncing around, but driven by the volume of new business. What we build into our modeling curves is the maturity of the book of business. And so what you'll see over time is each cohort will begin to produce what our long-term returns are. So it is due to the level of new business.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then I guess my follow-up then would just be for Jay Benet on the investment income side. And it seems like a lot of the discussions around lower investment yields, but something [indiscernible] to us a little bit. It looks like the
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then I guess my follow-up then would just be for Jay Benet on the investment income side. And it seems like a lot of the discussions around lower investment yields, but something [indiscernible] to us a little bit. It looks like the average invested assets were down about a little more than 1% on the quarter. And it also looked like there was, in the 10-Q, an allusion to a $0.5 billion payment on the asbestos side that's coming in the second quarter. So just trying to understand, when you think about that $25 million to $30 million quarterly drag, is that contemplating sort of a lower level of invested assets? Or should we think about that as all just being driven by your view of lower investment rates?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Benet. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the Direct Acti
componenttext: This is Jay Benet. It is a combination of our view as to what the rate environment looks like as well as what the average invested assets are and will be. As you recall, in the first quarter of last year, we had a large payment to finalize the Direct Action's settlement for asbestos. That brought the average down a little bit. And as you rightly point out, we're expecting to make a final payment on the PPG settlement when other parties finalize some of the remaining issues, which are -- we don't view as significant issues, in the second quarter. We expect to make that payment in the second quarter, so that will have an impact as well. Something else that affects the average invested assets, some of our assets are denominated in foreign currency. So you do have some currency exchange taking place, where, in effect, the assets are still the same, just the currency-adjusted value is a little lower. But those are the 2 primary things, the 2 asbestos payments, that bring it down.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Charles Sebaski from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Charles Sebaski from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hoping to just get a little bit more color on -- if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what is talked ab
componenttext: First question is on that new business growth in Business Insurance. Hoping to just get a little bit more color on -- if that's coming from sort of disruption or whether or not -- it seems like the growth relative to the pricing trend or what is talked about in the industry is a little bit upside down. I mean, it's a little surprising, the size of it. So I would appreciate any help you could give on what you think is really causing that expansion.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there's certainly nothing different in our -- the return thresholds that we're seeking that's driving that. And both increased levels of retention and new bu
componenttext: Sure. It's Alan. Again, I'll start. We don't think there's anything different in the pricing, and there's certainly nothing different in our -- the return thresholds that we're seeking that's driving that. And both increased levels of retention and new business are contributing to it. I think that's an important point. And we really start with what I said in my opening remarks. We think it's the quality and breadth of our products and services, the talent we have in the field, the relationships we have with our producers. All that always puts us in a great position to win. And on top of that, this quarter, as both Brian and I noted, there was some disruption in the marketplace, and given our stability out there, we do think we benefit from that. It's hard, probably impossible, for any of us to try to put a finer point on the allocation of dollars to one cause or another, but we do think all those things coming together resulted in the higher new business levels.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then I guess for Doreen, I saw earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners policies. I'm just curious, any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using te
componenttext: All right. And then I guess for Doreen, I saw earlier in the quarter, you guys had a press release out that you're offering a discount for connected Homeowners policies. I'm just curious, any update on kind of that or any of the other initiatives using technology into personal lines, be it pricing, be it UBI, et cetera?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know we have IntelliDrive, where we do offer a discount. It's mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and, perha
componenttext: We're still a little new in the space. I'll tell you a couple of things that we have. You know we have IntelliDrive, where we do offer a discount. It's mileage-based. We're actually looking further into that based on the acts that are available and, perhaps, moving beyond mileage. So that's obviously on the list. Second, we did roll out in a couple of pilot states for use -- for individuals, when they're using their car for Uber. And what it really does is it covers what's called the trolling period until there's a match. Then the coverage is clear that there isn't any personal insurance coverage. And then this discount for connected homes. And if you think about it, similar to what we would do for someone who has an alarm or something of that sort, but we do have both of our claims -- both of our homes of that Claim U are connected homes, so we can study how the data comes in. We can study what that changes about the underwriting process and the claim process. And we're also a member of CNET, which has a very sophisticated connected home in Kentucky, and we're the only insurer on that CNET home board looking for all the applications in the connected space. So that's just a little of what we've got going on.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question for Doreen. Just wanted to follow up on the Personal Auto side. I believe you said frequency was up 3% this quarter for Personal Auto. Curious as to what it was last year. And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so
componenttext: The first question for Doreen. Just wanted to follow up on the Personal Auto side. I believe you said frequency was up 3% this quarter for Personal Auto. Curious as to what it was last year. And have you seen any negative impact from the warmer weather so far in the Northeast in the first quarter on your frequency?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to give you a really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 point for frequency and 2.5 points for severity. And that's been something
componenttext: I'm going to give you a really detailed answer, but the first thing I want to do is correct that we've seen frequency of 3%. We've seen a normalized trend of 3%, which includes 0.5 point for frequency and 2.5 points for severity. And that's been something that we've basically had baked into our results for 2 to 3 years at this point. So let me just go back a little bit on frequency because I know we've talked a lot about it. We talked a lot about it at [indiscernible]. We know that others have commented on frequency in the industry. Some have commented that they're seeing higher frequency. Some have not commented at all. So we don't feel like it's the thing that's just ripping through the industry. It's affecting very specific companies. And the most important thing for us is where you're starting from, what assumptions have you made. So we have not assumed flat frequency for a number of years, it's been 0.5 point. The other thing I'll -- and we may have talked about this last quarter, so I apologize if it's repetitive. But in '14, there were some observations that frequency was dropping. We analyzed that very, very carefully and really didn't think it was systemic or sustainable. And so at that point, while we recognized the financial impact of that lower frequency for '14, we went into '15 assuming that trend was going to go back to where it was, and it did. And so the 0.5 point remains unchanged. The trend remains unchanged, and it really goes back to where you start from.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. And it seems that the growth was faster in Middle Market and Other Business Insurance, where pricing is maybe slightly weaker than the Sele
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The second question is just a follow-up on the new business growth on the Business Insurance. And it seems that the growth was faster in Middle Market and Other Business Insurance, where pricing is maybe slightly weaker than the Select accounts. So was that just a coincidence? Or just curious as to what's happening between those segments.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think this is -- so this is Brian. I think in Middle Market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so I
componenttext: Yes. I think this is -- so this is Brian. I think in Middle Market, in particular, we've been doing a lot of things with our process and our people to be really active in the marketplace. Our flow in new business opportunities there are up a bit. And so I think part of it is the activity we've had. I think it's also linked to -- and again, as Alan said, you can't draw perfect connections here, but there is disruption in the marketplace amongst some significant competitors. And I think our strong position with agents and brokers and the breadth of products that we have and capabilities have really helped us there. So I think we're very comfortable. As I also said, we're obsessing over the quality, so we're looking at all of those deals. In the Other Business Insurance world, there are some specific opportunities. We've got a transportation company, Northland Insurance, that does the smaller end of the trucking business, so not the large fleets primarily. They've had some neat opportunities. There's been some opportunity in the inland marine and boiler business, again, somewhat a result of some actions that other carriers have taken. So I think all of those things have added up to it. And it's not -- I think -- I guess the main point: it's not tied directly to pricing and price change opportunity.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jay. It's Alan. When we talk about underlying underwriting margin in the outlook, what we're really talking about are dollars, not the combined ratio. And you could look at that as opposite sides of the coin, but we, for instance, would consider vol
componenttext: Sure, Jay. It's Alan. When we talk about underlying underwriting margin in the outlook, what we're really talking about are dollars, not the combined ratio. And you could look at that as opposite sides of the coin, but we, for instance, would consider volume in there as well. But we've got the outlook being broadly consistent, and obviously, we think about that as margin of something around the prior year period. But in that outlook, earned margin is a little bit negative, and we've got an expectation for large losses improving and volume also improving, and those 2 things adding give us an outlook of broadly consistent.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. All right. And then my follow-up question is -- clearly, we had elevated first quarter catastrophe losses. Given all the destruction in Houston from the floods, if you can give us your perspective on that. And I know flooding isn't typically covere
componenttext: I see. All right. And then my follow-up question is -- clearly, we had elevated first quarter catastrophe losses. Given all the destruction in Houston from the floods, if you can give us your perspective on that. And I know flooding isn't typically covered for things like Homeowners, but it would impact comprehensive auto or maybe some commercial property insurance. If you could help us out there.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you're asking the question, why is the effective tax rate lower this quarter than it had been in the prior year quarter? And the effective tax rate is always going to be driven by the mix of tax-exempt income and fully taxable income. So what
componenttext: Yes, I think you're asking the question, why is the effective tax rate lower this quarter than it had been in the prior year quarter? And the effective tax rate is always going to be driven by the mix of tax-exempt income and fully taxable income. So what you're seeing here is the taxable income -- fully taxable income as a proportion of the total getting a little less because of the cat activity primarily. The change in the non-fully taxable income, the tax-exempt income, was pretty de minimis. So if you do a math on that, you'll see that's the effect on the effective tax rate.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Sarah DeWitt from JPMorgan.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on the Business Insurance underlying margin, is it fair to say that it's stable this year mostly because there was higher non-cat weather in 2015? But then as you look out going forward, it would probably deteriorate because prices are below
componenttext: Following up on the Business Insurance underlying margin, is it fair to say that it's stable this year mostly because there was higher non-cat weather in 2015? But then as you look out going forward, it would probably deteriorate because prices are below loss cost inflation. Is that a fair assumption? Or am I off?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It wasn't so much weather in Business Insurance as it was higher volume of large losses in the last 3 quarters of last year. And one of the reasons that we give outlook for 3 or 4 quarters is because just our perspective beyond that gets unreli
componenttext: Yes, sure. It wasn't so much weather in Business Insurance as it was higher volume of large losses in the last 3 quarters of last year. And one of the reasons that we give outlook for 3 or 4 quarters is because just our perspective beyond that gets unreliable. So I don't know, but what I would point you to is the way we've been able to manage returns across all 3 business segments over a long period of time throughout a bunch of different conditions. And so you look at what Doreen and Greg and Michael have done in Personal Insurance by taking some difficult actions and repositioning that business and rolling out a new product. You look at what Tom Kunkel did in Bond & Specialty in a bunch of credit-sensitive businesses through a very difficult period and a financial crisis. Think about what we've done in Business Insurance going back to 2010, when you look at the -- we went back, then we looked at the outlook for returns and realized that we had to do some things differently. So your perspective that it might fall off beyond where we're giving guidance for suggests purely current course and speed, and I would say that we're at current course and speed now because we like product returns. And when we get to a point in time where we don't like product returns, then we'll do different things. So we -- I wouldn't necessarily draw the conclusion you're drawing. But I don't know for sure. We're all speculating beyond 3 or 4 quarters.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the other things that makes it very challenging is we do talk about loss trend and the loss trend is off of a starting point, and sometimes we adjust the starting point. You've heard us talk about base year movement. That comes about when we see fa
componenttext: One of the other things that makes it very challenging is we do talk about loss trend and the loss trend is off of a starting point, and sometimes we adjust the starting point. You've heard us talk about base year movement. That comes about when we see favorable development and try to evaluate, well, what does that mean for the very loss picks [ph] that we had that -- with the starting point for the loss trends that go forward. So it is, as Alan said, a pretty complicated set of variables that go into it, and the ability to look out much beyond 3 quarters or 4 quarters is a bit challenging.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just on -- in auto insurance, this top line growth there was very strong. Could you just elaborate on what was driving that? And is that a level that we should view as sustainable?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've talked about, Sarah, is that the percentages probably won't be the same because our base is growing. And as you probably recall, Quantum 2.0 rolled out over a couple of years and even including 3 more states this year: California, North C
componenttext: Well, what we've talked about, Sarah, is that the percentages probably won't be the same because our base is growing. And as you probably recall, Quantum 2.0 rolled out over a couple of years and even including 3 more states this year: California, North Carolina and Massachusetts. And so we think that the percentage will moderate, but we're not anticipating that the product would be less competitive. We also are pleased to see, and so are our agents, that they're actually getting a disproportionate share of their new business from captives in the direct marketplace, which is something that we talk to them about. So I would say the percentage, we definitely don't think will stay the same, but probably from a count perspective, we expect it to continue to perform at similar levels.

componenttext: No, Brian. What we did as part of this assessment was looked at whether our current infrastructure, our current claim handling and our current product could support that. componenttext: Great. And just a quick one for Jay. Jay, it looks like your pension expense down -- or in benefits, down about $17 million on a year-over-year basis. Is that something we should expect kind of going forward? And where does that hit in your P&L?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, in terms of the P&L, it's in a couple of places because pension expense, of course, relates to headcount, and headcount ends up in G&A as well as ULAE. So it's in more than one spot. But as it relates to what's taking place in the pension area
componenttext: Okay. Well, in terms of the P&L, it's in a couple of places because pension expense, of course, relates to headcount, and headcount ends up in G&A as well as ULAE. So it's in more than one spot. But as it relates to what's taking place in the pension area, you may recall, in the 10-K, we provided a disclosure saying that we were adopting a new methodology that went into the estimation of pension, and that dealt with using a yield curve approach rather than spot rate for looking at the interest and service costs to coincide with how the PBO was being calculated. And that did have a benefit, and that will be a benefit that carries on into the future.

componenttext: Well, there's nothing about the current level of disruption that's causing us to look at that in the sense that we look at that all the time. We're always looking for opportunities to expand our product set and to drive our competitive advantages and capabilities into new lines of business, new products. So we certainly don't wait for a moment in time to do that.

componenttext: Yes. Jay, this is Brian. Yes, I mean, the 88% retention in Middle Market was very, very strong and clearly, would be at the upper end. We dissect where we're getting the retention. We feel great that it's about 90% in our best business. But our experience in the business would be that that's a -- those are very tough levels to sustain.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So given that, Brian, did you guys ever think, gee, we could push a bit more on pricing, maybe let that retention settle in at still phenomenal 84%, 85%? I know it's a tough balancing act, but is that part of your thought process?
componenttext: So given that, Brian, did you guys ever think, gee, we could push a bit more on pricing, maybe let that retention settle in at still phenomenal 84%, 85%? I know it's a tough balancing act, but is that part of your thought process?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So every single day in the marketplace, with every transaction, that's what our underwriters are doing. They're working with agents and brokers in the Middle Market and in the Other Business Insurance stuff account by account, and they're trying to determ
componenttext: So every single day in the marketplace, with every transaction, that's what our underwriters are doing. They're working with agents and brokers in the Middle Market and in the Other Business Insurance stuff account by account, and they're trying to determine what's the appropriate thing to do for that account. You can get caught up in the arithmetic of what you just said, and we do ourselves at times, but it's not as straight a line to say, well, if you reduce retention 2 points and you raise prices X, that's not exactly how the marketplace dynamics work. But we are always trying to look at the retention rate tradeoff and looking at that in the context, first and foremost, of the return that we believe we're generating on that account or that book of business and is it appropriate and where do we want to go. So we're balancing it all the time.

componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Second Quarter Results Teleconference for Travelers. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded on July 21, 2016. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Ms. Gabriella Nawi, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Nawi, you may begin.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tina. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers' discussion of our 2016 second quarter results. Hopefully, all of you have seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation released earlier this morning. All of these materials
componenttext:
Thank you, Tina. Good morning, and welcome to Travelers' discussion of our 2016 second quarter results. Hopefully, all of you have seen our press release, financial supplement and webcast presentation released earlier this morning. All of these materials can be found on our website, at www.travelers.com, under the Investor Section. 
Speaking today will be Alan Schnitzer, Chief Executive Officer; Jay Benet, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer; and Brian MacLean, President and Chief Operating Officer. They will discuss the financial results of our businesses and the current market environment. They will refer to the webcast presentation as they go through prepared remarks, and then, we will take questions. 
In addition, other members of senior management are in the room including Bill Heyman, Vice Chairman and Chief Investment Officer; Michael Klein, Executive Vice President and President, Personal Insurance; Tom Kunkel, Executive Vice President and President, Bond and Specialty Insurance; and Greg Executive Vice President and President of Business Insurance. 
Before I turn it over to Alan, I'd like to draw your attention to the note included at the end of the webcast. Our presentation today include forward-looking statements. The company cautions investors that any forward-looking statements involves risks and uncertainties, and is not a guarantee of future performance. Actual results may differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements due to a variety of factors. These factors are described in our earnings press release and in our most recent 10-Q filed with the SEC. We do not undertake any obligation to update forward-looking statements. Also, in our remarks or responses to questions, we may mention some non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations are included in our recent earnings press release, financial supplement and other materials that are available on the Investor Section on our website. And now, Alan Schnitzer.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported second quarter operating income of $649 million or $2.20 per share, and an operating return on equity of 11.6%. Our underwriting results remain strong
componenttext:
Thank you, Gabby. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we reported second quarter operating income of $649 million or $2.20 per share, and an operating return on equity of 11.6%. Our underwriting results remain strong as reflected in our 93.1% combined ratio for the quarter, despite the impact of higher catastrophe and non-cat weather-related costs year-over-year. 
For the 6 months, we reported operating income of $1.35 billion or $4.52 per share and an operating return on equity of 12%. Given the cumulative impact of declining interest rates on our investment portfolio, and also relative to the fresh lows in the risk-free rate, we felt terrific about the returns we continue to generate. Our expertise and risk selection and pricing, our thoughtful and consistent investment strategy and our active approach to capital management, all come together to enable to achieve our objectives of delivering superior returns and creating shareholder value. 
Turning to production, the second quarter was another example of the successful execution of our marketplace strategies. We're very pleased with the record volume of premium that we brought in the quarter. And we continue to be very pleased with the model returns in the business writing. In our commercial businesses, retentions remain high and no premium change was positive. Underneath that, consistent with our very granular approach to execution, in middle market, we retained 19% of the premium from our best performance accounts with only modest decline in renewal rate change on that business. 
One our poor performance accounts, we achieved renewal rate change in excess of lost trend. You might have noticed that renewal rate change in domestic business insurance was slightly positive as compared to slightly negative in the second quarter. And annual rate change in the market improved by 4-point. We don't forecast rate and we're not calling a bottom, but the significance of this to us is that the market remains remarkably stable and we're generally successful and achieving our written return objectives. 
In terms of new business, we are actively seeking and finding opportunities that meet our return thresholds. And we delivered strong new business growth in our commercial businesses including 10% growth in new business and domestic business insurance. 
In Personal Insurance, net written premiums were 9% to a recordable $2.1 billion with accelerating momentum in both Auto and Homeowners. New business was up 21% year-over-year, driven by the success of the Quantum product. Quantum Auto 2.0 continues to meet our financial expectations and are successfully enhancing our market position. Our success in the marketplace across all our businesses really speak to the value of the talent that we have in the home office and in the field. And their ability to leverage our data and analytics and work with our distribution partners to deliver great products and services at their prices to our customers. 
Franchise value matters. Before turning the call over to Jay Benet, I'd like to acknowledge and thank all of our colleagues in the claim organization for their extraordinary efforts in handling the claims of our customers, affected by severe weather and fire so far this year. These experts are on the frontline for us delivering on the promise we extend with every policy that we write, and it has been a very active year so far for them. Their responsiveness and expertise are great to our customers and an important competitive advantage for us. 
In Canada, where we felt significant wildfires in Fort McMurray area, both our customers and we benefited from the work we've done to replicate our U.S. claim model, which enables us to respond to large-scale events with our own highly trained professionals and resources, without resorting to independent adjusters. So all in all, results in the quarter first, particularly the weather and wildfires and continued excellent execution in the marketplace. And with that, I'll turn it over to Jay Benet.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. As I did in the first quarter, I'd like to start by saying that we're pleased with our results, operating income of $649 million and operating return on equity of 11.6%, despite they being lower than in the prior year quarter. This reduction
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. As I did in the first quarter, I'd like to start by saying that we're pleased with our results, operating income of $649 million and operating return on equity of 11.6%, despite they being lower than in the prior year quarter. This reduction did not result from significant changes in underlying business trends. Notably, as indicated on Page 4 of the webcast, the quarter-over-quarter decrease in operating income was impacted by, among other things, PCS cat events and lower fixed income, net investment income. 
Losses from PCS cat events with net or exceeded our threshold for recording its cat, was $79 million higher after tax than in the prior year quarter. The losses from PCS CAT events that filed below our cat thresholds, which we recorded as part of non-cap weather related losses within underlying underwriting results were $56 million after tax than in the prior year quarter. 
And fixed income NII was $21 million lower after tax, primarily due to the continuing low interest rate environment as we had anticipated in the outlook section of our first quarter 2016 10-Q. Everything else was pretty much a wash. 
We continue to experience net favorable prior year result development, which totaled $288 million pretax or $192 million after tax this quarter, up from $207 million pretax or $133 million after tax in the prior year quarter. The business in international insurance, net favorable development of $138 million pretax or $94 million after tax, primarily resulted from better-than-expected loss in domestic workers comp.  For accident years 2006 and prior, an accident year 2015. Better-than-expected loss experience in domestic general liability for accident years 2011 and 2015 and better-than-expected loss experience in our European operations, partially offset by an $82 million pretax or $53 million after tax increase to environmental reserves. 
In Bond and Specialty Insurance, net favorable development of $150 million pretax or $98 million after tax, primarily resulted from better-than-expected loss experience. And fidelity and Surety for accident years, 2010, 2013 and 2014 and better-than-expected loss experience in GL for accident years, 2007 through 2011. 
Year-to-date, on a combined basis where all of our U.S. subs, all accident years have developed favorably or had deminimus unfavorable development. In addition, other than commercial multi-parallel or product lines have developed favorably year-to-date. While CMP has developed unfavorably by $42 million year-to-date, you may recall, my telling you in the first quarter, that there was an offsetting favorable development in the property product line as middle market property losses that had been recorded in the property line at year end 2015 were subsequently determined to be CMP related. 
Operating cash flows of $443 million was very strong, particularly recognizing that there were net of the $524 million payment we made this quarter, as final settlement of the PPG litigation. We ended the quarter with holding company liquidity of $1.75 billion and all of our capital ratios were at or better than their target levels. 
Net unrealized investment gains increased to approximately $3.6 billion pretax or $2.3 billion after tax, up from $2 billion and $1.3 billion, respectively, at the beginning of the year, while book value per share of $85.73 and adjusted book value per share of $77.61 increased 7% and 3%, respectively, also from the beginning of the year. 
We continue to generate much more capital than we need to support our business. And consistent with our ongoing capital management strategy, we returned $747 million of excess capital to our shareholders this quarter through dividends of $197 million of share repurchases of $550 million. Year-to-date, we returned over $1.5 billion to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. Before turning the microphone over to Brian, there's 1 additional topic I'd like to cover or cap reinsurance coverage. 
In addition to our corporate cat aggregate which had renewed at the beginning of the year, our cap reinsurance included cap bonds that were specific to the Northeast U.S. along with the Northeast gen cap trading. 
With respect to the cat bonds, 1, that had provided up to $300 million of coverage for certain losses, expired as scheduled in May 2016, and given our current risk profile, we decided not to replace them. With respect to the remaining cat bond, which will not expire until May 2018, the attachment point and maximum limit will reset as required annually to adjust the model expected loss of the layer within the predetermined range. For the year beginning May, 16, 2016, we will begin recovering amounts under this cat bond as losses in the covered area for single occurrence, reaching additional attachment amount of $1.968 billion. The full $300 million coverage amount is available on a proportional basis until such covered losses reach a maximum $2.468 billion. 
And finally, our Northeast Gen Cat treaty renewed on July 1. This treaty provides up to $800 million, part of $850 million of coverage, subject to $2.25 billion retention. The certain losses arising from hurricanes, tornadoes, health storms, earthquakes, and winter storms or freeze losses from Virginia to main. A more complete description of our cat reinsurance coverage in pulling a description of earthquake and international coverage is included in our second quarter 10-Q, which we filed earlier today as well as in our 2015 10-K. 
While the total cost of these treaties is small, in relation to our operational income, we were able to save some money by not replacing the expiring cat bond. And with that, let me turn the microphone over to Brian.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. In business and international insurance, we're pleased with the results this quarter. In domestic business insurance, we achieved a very strong retention along with the modest increase in renewal rate change versus the first quarter and highe
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. In business and international insurance, we're pleased with the results this quarter. In domestic business insurance, we achieved a very strong retention along with the modest increase in renewal rate change versus the first quarter and higher levels of new business. Our strategy has not changed as we strive to retain our best-performing accounts, get rate where needed and right new business when it meets our target returns. 
It has been our strategy for some time. And as a result, will continue to be viewed by the stable and financially strong market by our distributors and customers. Along with the meaningful competitive advantages that we deliver, this consistent leadership position is resulting in additional growth opportunities for us. 
Turning to the financial results for the segment, operating income was $393 million with the combined ratio of $97.5 million. Cat losses for the quarter were $143 million net after-tax, which included $61 million from the Canadian wildfires. Excluding the Canadian fires, cat losses were slightly higher than the prior year quarter. The underlying combined ratio, which excludes the impact of cat in prior-year reserve development, was 95.5, up 2.4 points compared to the second quarter of 2015. The loss ratio increased by 1.7 points, driven primarily by non-cat weather, which was higher than prior year quarter and our expectation. The expense ratio was up 7 tenths of a point over last year, driven primarily by commissions as the second quarter of 2015 benefited from a one-time favorable adjustment. 
Net written premiums for the quarter were in line with the prior year quarter with domestic business insurance premiums, up about 2%. Given the returns that we are generating in this business, our focus continues to be on retention. And so, we were very pleased with that retention remains at 85% for the quarter, renewal premium change was just over 2 points, including renewal rate change that was slightly positive. New business of $525 million was up 10% versus the second quarter of 2015. 
Turning to the individual businesses within Business Insurance. Beginning with select, we achieved retention of 82% and renewal premium change of nearly 6%. Rate change was down slightly versus the first quarter of 2016, while exposure was in line with recent period and new business was up slightly year-over-year. In middle market, retention remained very strong at 87% with renewal premium change of about 0.51 in line with recent quarters. 
In terms of new business opportunities, given our leadership position in the market, submissions were up year-over-year. Accordingly, we had more opportunities to quote on the types and classes of business we find attractive and to grow our new business while maintaining our return thresholds. 
In Other Business Insurance, retention of 82% was up point year-over-year, while renewal premium change was 0.5. and new business of $154 million was consistent with the second quarter of 2015. As we've mentioned in the past, our business insurance includes our National Property Business. While there continues to be some rate pressure in this business, returns remain attractive, and as a result, retention is our priority. 
As you can see, on Page 13 of the webcast, excluding national property, renewal rate change or Other Business Insurance remain positive and was relatively consistent with recent quarters. In International, net written premiums for the second quarter were down about 12% quarter-over-quarter, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, net written premiums were down about 9%, driven by disciplined underwriting actions in our U.K. business, along with lower economic activity impacting the Marine and energy lines of our Lloyd's business. 
New business of $107 million was up 67% year-over-year, driven primarily by Optima, our new strategic Personal Lines Auto product in Canada, which was modeled after our U.S.-based Quantum Auto 2.0 product. So all in a good quarter for the segment with strong production and profitability. 
I'll turn now to Bond and Specialty Insurance where we had another terrific quarter. Operating income of $202 million was up significantly from the prior year quarter, driven by a higher level of net favorable prior year reserve development. The underlying combined ratio of 80.9% remains exceptionally strong. As for topline, net written premiums for the quarter were in line with the prior year, as growth in Management Liability was offset by lower Surety premium. The lower Surety volume was due almost entirely to favorable one-time reinsurance impacts in the prior year quarter. 
Across our Management Liability business, retention remained at historically high levels and new business volumes were up. As we continue to execute our strategy of retaining our best accounts, underwriting more business in our return adequate product segment. We continue to feel great about this segment's performance. 
In Personal Insurance, results were again strong and remain particularly pleased with our ability to add topline growth at appropriate financial returns. Net written premiums for the quarter, up $2.1 billion were an all-time high with double-digit growth in Agency Auto, while growth also accelerated in Agency Homeowners and other. In both products, we continue to produce strong retention and new business levels. Agent and consumer receptivity to Quantum Auto 2.0 remains exceptional and importantly, as significant amount of Quantum Auto 2.0 business are now coming through their renewal cycles. We're pleased with the retention rates we're seeing on those policies. 
In Homeowners, our growth momentum is building due to crossover benefits from Quantum Auto 2.0 as well as pricing changes and improvements to agent and customer experience. 
Turning to profitability, operating income for the segment was down compared to the prior year quarter, due primarily to lower net favorable prior-year reserve development. The underlying combined ratio of 89.5% was in line with our expectations, but up about point from the prior year, driven by the impact of the significant new business volume in recent years and normal quarterly volatility in weather and other loss activity. 
In Agency Auto, the 101.3 combined ratio included 2.7 points in cash, primarily resulting from hail storms. Weather also impacted the underwriting combined ratio with 1.7 points of non-GAAP weather-related losses, which is approximately 1 point higher than both our expectations and the second quarter of 2015. 
The remaining increase in the underlying combined ratio was driven by the high levels of new business that I just mentioned. As we've noted before, the Quantum Auto 2.0 business is price 2 to our long-term target returns and loss experiences for performing in-line with our expectations. 
Turning to Agency Homeowners and other, underlying financial results remain strong. The second quarter underlying combined ratio of 78.2% is well within our target return levels as we continue to execute our disciplined underwriting and pricing strategies. So overall, for Personal Insurance, we feel great about the growth in the financial return that the business in generating. 
Before I turn it back to Gabby, I would like to take a moment to recognize who and our retirement from Travelers' effective September 1 of this year. Over the past 30 years, Doreen has played an important role on our management team and we wish her well as she enjoy the new chapter of her life. With that, let me turn it over to Gabby.

componenttext: Kai, this is Brian. I will start couple of broad dynamics. Not surprisingly, auto was the line where we're saying the more positive pricing movement. Comp is, I think, the line with the most pressure. And that's, I think, really consistent with workers comp, if you've seen what is coming out of NCCI and other competitors, that's not surprising. From an account size perspective, larger accounts under more pressure. So we've talked a lot and others have talked about large property business. We think that's somewhat consistent with the returns that have been in that business. But some pressures there, I think, even larger casualty business is under a little more pressure than the middle and small type of business. Think from an industry perspective, there is anything appreciable. But that would be the broad stroke.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then the follow-up on the reserve side, looks like reserve continue to be strong. And I just want to focus on sort of 3 areas. One is that, what's releasing 2017, is that sort of like -- is that too early for a long tail on the business. And secondl
componenttext: Okay. Then the follow-up on the reserve side, looks like reserve continue to be strong. And I just want to focus on sort of 3 areas. One is that, what's releasing 2017, is that sort of like -- is that too early for a long tail on the business. And secondly, the $82 million Environmental charges, looks like we are having those amounts for at least, for the last 5 to 6 years. Just wondering any, like, why wouldn't you, if the pattern is there, why wouldn't you book a big charge of funds. And then the 30s is pretty strong, like bond, especially continue to release any underlying loss cost trend there would be appreciated.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Benet. Looks like, take them in order. So as far as workers comp, you're absolutely right, when you have a very long tail line of business, you look very, very carefully at things have happened in the short-term and don't necessarily area reac
componenttext: This is Jay Benet. Looks like, take them in order. So as far as workers comp, you're absolutely right, when you have a very long tail line of business, you look very, very carefully at things have happened in the short-term and don't necessarily area react to them. In the case of workers comp, what you're seeing here is favorable development in 2015 that related to relatively short component of it, relating to medical where medical bills coming quickly, they get resolved quickly. And the assumption that we had put in there for medical inflation was just too high. So while the line itself is a longtail line, there are components offered that are more short tail, and that's primarily lower and reacted to there. As far as the environmental piece is concerned, I think, if you look at us, as well as the industry, you'll see similar pattern, if you will. People trying to, at various points in time, estimate what the ultimate is going to be for Environmental losses. And recognizing that, you're dealing with something that is a very difficult kind of reserve to fully evaluate. So in doing so, you have to make various assumptions as to what the future is going to look like in terms of new claims, new policyholders, what the average frequency and severity might be associated with things that have been reported or not quarter. And it's those assumptions that you're constantly updating as time goes on. So what we disclosed, I point it to the 10-Q, what we disclosed this year is actually very similar to what we've disclosed in prior periods and what you've seen other companies disclosed that there really hasn't been a change in the environment, per se, things have gotten a little better, but the rate of them getting better has just been less -- previously assumed or hope for. And that's a chunk of the reserve addition. In addition to that, subject to judicial rulings or other things to take place episodically in various jurisdictions. And now there was 1 that came out of the northwest increased modestly, some of their claim cost there that we also recognized. And then finally, on the Bond and Specialty, this was a quarter for a fairly large prior year reserve development benefit. I wouldn't say there was anything unusual about it. This is, as you know, it's high severity, low-frequency business. It's 1 where information emerges slowly as it emerges, you're always evaluating whether or not it's blossomed to a level where you really feel action is appropriate. So there are things that had been taking place whether it's in items related to the financial crisis, whatever that we have been watching like things quarter point this quarter where we recognized that there was appropriate to take some reserve action. There wasn't any one product line, it wasn't anyone particular claim or things like that, it was pretty much spread across the whole Management Liability and Surety book of business.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is for Brian, I was hoping a little bit more color on what's driving the solid new business growth in middle markets. I think you mentioned submissions are up. But I guess, sort of like over the past couple of quarters, it has been prett
componenttext: My first question is for Brian, I was hoping a little bit more color on what's driving the solid new business growth in middle markets. I think you mentioned submissions are up. But I guess, sort of like over the past couple of quarters, it has been pretty strong and just sort of what you're seeing on the new business on ?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a couple of factors. We believe, as I tried to say in my comments, driven by the factor, I think we're pretty strong position in the marketplace. We have been executing in a very stable and effective way, I think for a long period of time. We
componenttext: I think it's a couple of factors. We believe, as I tried to say in my comments, driven by the factor, I think we're pretty strong position in the marketplace. We have been executing in a very stable and effective way, I think for a long period of time. We've got some real competitive advantages. The overall market is pretty stable, but there has been pretty well publicized dislocation, in at least the couple of very large carriers have been very open about taking profit improvement actions. And so that's created some specific opportunities. But I think, we think more broadly, has also created a little bit of a mood in the marketplace of flight to quality. So like I said, we've seen our submission activity up a decent amount. And we've also consistent with that, been driving the message to our organization, not strategically to do anything different with returns, but to be more active. And to be out there quoting more. So just to be blunt about it, we're pushing our place pretty hard right now to be a real active in the marketplace and get out the quotes and not compromise on returns. But try to meet the opportunity of the submission activity. And that's been paying off and specifically our core middle market, commercial accounts business and the construction areas.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, I would add to that part of our motivation pushing little more activities, just where returns are, product to marketplace after 5 or so years of price increases. So there is lot out there that's potentially attractive to us, consistent. This is rea
componenttext: Brian, I would add to that part of our motivation pushing little more activities, just where returns are, product to marketplace after 5 or so years of price increases. So there is lot out there that's potentially attractive to us, consistent. This is really important, consistent with our return objectives. So we're not making any compromises on that.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: okay. That make a lot of sense. I guess, another question was just on look at the margin trajectory in Agency Auto and how to think about that on a go-forward basis. I guess, couple of things that have been that have seem to be lost, loss ratio some, there is the new business drag. Then, there is the elevated non-cat weather. But something that we were little bit -- interesting was looking at the thank you. It looks like the language looking in the 2017 was that margins remained kind of where you have been. And I'm just kind of curious, as you lap the elevated new business and you get rid of the lower non-cat weather, why would margins not be improving kind of as you look out in the 2017?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, just couple quick comments. And then I will pass it to Michael. Certainly, we view that the non-cat weather is episodic. And so we think that should absolutely return to normal level. On the new business dynamic, the good news is that we conti
componenttext: So I think, just couple quick comments. And then I will pass it to Michael. Certainly, we view that the non-cat weather is episodic. And so we think that should absolutely return to normal level. On the new business dynamic, the good news is that we continue to write some significant levels of new business to that product. So we feel great that we are building real embedded value in that portfolio. But it is going to take longer. The stronger the production topline is, the longer it is going to take for that to really to work through the loss ratio. The other point I'd make is, the Quantum 2.0 product also was designed to have a lower expense ratio and a little bit higher on loss side. So you have to look at the combined in total to get that product. So...

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, just clarify something. One of the things we actually added to the queue this quarter was in the outlook section, we have previously spoken to underlying underwriting margins. So we thought it was important to add combined ratio, because people oft
componenttext: Brian, just clarify something. One of the things we actually added to the queue this quarter was in the outlook section, we have previously spoken to underlying underwriting margins. So we thought it was important to add combined ratio, because people often use those terms interchangeably. And as you know, the combined ratio is assumption of the premium volume, whereas, the margins are just dollars. And just to clarify what we're saying here in the queue is, for Auto, it's I think what we're talking about, the early part of '17, the company expects underlying underwriting margins, the dollars to be slightly higher because of what's taking place with writing higher volumes of business, that's profitable. But writing higher percentage of new business relative to the base is also causing a slight uptick in the underlying combined ratio. So you have this feature here where the dollars are going up, at the same time, that the combined ratio is going up. So I just want to clarify that.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, I think that's helpful. I think I was little bit confused by that.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, I think that's helpful. I think I was little bit confused by that.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other factor just to note is, it's not all this new business impact from what we are writing. As Michael explained a second ago, we haven't had this last quarter or so this favorable non-weather loss activity. And as we also highlighted in 10-Q, we ex
componenttext: The other factor just to note is, it's not all this new business impact from what we are writing. As Michael explained a second ago, we haven't had this last quarter or so this favorable non-weather loss activity. And as we also highlighted in 10-Q, we expect that to return to a more normal level. So that's also having a go forward basis, a slight adverse impact.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Michael, underneath just to reiterate, right Quantum Auto 2.0 is price of the same return level  as the book of business has been quite. So it really is the dynamic of preponderance of newer. Think of it as a younger business, right, the portfolio
componenttext: This is Michael, underneath just to reiterate, right Quantum Auto 2.0 is price of the same return level  as the book of business has been quite. So it really is the dynamic of preponderance of newer. Think of it as a younger business, right, the portfolio is getting younger because of the outsized growth that we've seen over the last couple of years. But the long-term return targets for the product will remain consistent with where they have been.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 quick questions, probably these are follow-ups. And I apologize if I'm still not clear. This going back to the discussion of BII and what Randy was asking. If you excel all the moving parts, and just to focus on the underlying discussion on the negative
componenttext: 2 quick questions, probably these are follow-ups. And I apologize if I'm still not clear. This going back to the discussion of BII and what Randy was asking. If you excel all the moving parts, and just to focus on the underlying discussion on the negative loss cost trends versus on pricing, is it episodic as what you're seeing or is this the usual sort of trend line, i.e., you've talked about this in the past at overtime, this equation will get flipped. And now, we're at the point where it has flipped. I'm just trying to understand that.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not episodic. There is a trend there, but I think what we've told in the past is, there is some danger to looking at that very narrow definition of rate versus loss trend. And obviously, anybody could look at rate which is sort of around 0 and loss t
componenttext: It's not episodic. There is a trend there, but I think what we've told in the past is, there is some danger to looking at that very narrow definition of rate versus loss trend. And obviously, anybody could look at rate which is sort of around 0 and loss trend, which is North of 0, on a written basis. And it has been moving in that direction for some number of quarters. So as anybody, as we would've expected, as that earns in over time, there will be some negative pressure on margins. But what we've said in the past is you've got to look at that in the context of all the other moving pieces that impact underlying underwriting margin, things like we have a tax impact year-over-year this quarter, those expenses, those mix, all those other things going to that number. And what we've -- certainly this quarter is all that comes about to about a washed. And I guess, I'd also point you to the outlook where we will give you a sense of over the next four quarters or so that we would expect underlying underwriting margins obviously, subject to the volatility of weather and what not, to continue to be broadly consistent.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing evident emphasize, this is Brian, is that there's a lot of things in there that we have to react to. And there are other things in there that we are actively managing. And so you shouldn't have the impression that we are just sitting by, a
componenttext: The other thing evident emphasize, this is Brian, is that there's a lot of things in there that we have to react to. And there are other things in there that we are actively managing. And so you shouldn't have the impression that we are just sitting by, and as Alan just said, pricing is at roughly 0 this quarter rate and loss trend is something North of that, that we're just conceding that margins will recede. We are managing our mix, we're taking actions in underwriting selection, we're taking actions in claim execution, which are all impacting our loss trend. And then, we are reacting to whether volatility, et cetera, that might be moving through the business. So there is no denying that the of that narrow piece, the loss trend and the rate right now is a negative. We've said in the past that it's relatively modest when it continues to be relatively modest. And then, there are all the other impacts that are going through.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's a fair comment. The second question I had was just going back to the discussion on Quantum 2.0. In the past, when you talked about loss cost trends, frequency was pecked at 0.5, severity was at 2.5. Has there been any evolution in that numb
componenttext: Got it. That's a fair comment. The second question I had was just going back to the discussion on Quantum 2.0. In the past, when you talked about loss cost trends, frequency was pecked at 0.5, severity was at 2.5. Has there been any evolution in that number or it is still the same?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We didn't see anything different in the core underlying trends and what was going on in the auto book. We would be, at exactly those numbers you just said, about 0.5 frequency, 2.5 of severity. And as we have said in the Quantum Auto 2.0 specifically,
componenttext: No. We didn't see anything different in the core underlying trends and what was going on in the auto book. We would be, at exactly those numbers you just said, about 0.5 frequency, 2.5 of severity. And as we have said in the Quantum Auto 2.0 specifically, still running consistent with our loss expectations.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Our next question come from Charles Sebaski of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for getting in. I guess, I'd like to follow-up again on, I missed in Quantum 2.0 and the Agency Auto book. And the clarity, I realized disclosures in the queue. But how you guys expect the auto book to evolve out. I guess, the commentary of early '
componenttext: Thanks for getting in. I guess, I'd like to follow-up again on, I missed in Quantum 2.0 and the Agency Auto book. And the clarity, I realized disclosures in the queue. But how you guys expect the auto book to evolve out. I guess, the commentary of early '17 been plus or minus 16, which is plus or minus 15, and you say that your underwriting to a same return dynamic. But I guess, this has been a book and flux that coming out of 2011 and '12, underperforming and introduction of Quantum 2.0. Just where is the run rate on what you should -- what we should expect that -- there is so many moving parts. But it seem like there should be a story that was improving. And I guess, the commentary seems to be that it's maybe gotten as good as it's going to get. Is that right?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the message absolutely is not, this is as good as it's going to get. The core from a profitability perspective, let me start with the top line perspective, because story on Quantum 2.0. We have been pleasantly surprised with the traction the product ha
componenttext: So the message absolutely is not, this is as good as it's going to get. The core from a profitability perspective, let me start with the top line perspective, because story on Quantum 2.0. We have been pleasantly surprised with the traction the product has gotten in business in the marketplace. We clearly went in with an expectation that this would enhance growth and we've done better than our original expectation there. And you can see the numbers. So we feel good about that. And we are not sure where that's going to go exactly in the future, but we think that we're going to be able to sustain some pretty decent amount of growth going forward. From the profitability perspective, just as it's true of all business that we've ever written in this product, it matures over the years. And so there's  a tenure impact. And as Michael just said, the younger tenured business is typically not as profitable as we write the business where we are targeting a tenured, longer-term return and we're on track to do that. So as this portfolio matures, and as Quantum 2.0, as we get more and more of the aging of the book, we believe the trend should absolutely be improving profitability on this business.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, on that, could you give us some additional insight on the tenure, the curing of the Auto book. What is the average policy life for you guys on this. I guess, when I think of some commercial accounts, it might be longer. It seems that auto i
componenttext: Okay. I guess, on that, could you give us some additional insight on the tenure, the curing of the Auto book. What is the average policy life for you guys on this. I guess, when I think of some commercial accounts, it might be longer. It seems that auto is a quick return product. So this introduction of new growth, which really been strong. What's the timeline for curing on an auto book and how long do you average keep Auto policies?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I get into the specifics of the policy life expectancy, et cetera, but to give you a little bit more color, this is Michael, on aging of the auto book. You have to really think about both components of what's going on here, right. So fir
componenttext: I don't know that I get into the specifics of the policy life expectancy, et cetera, but to give you a little bit more color, this is Michael, on aging of the auto book. You have to really think about both components of what's going on here, right. So first, you need to think about a vintage and think about a book of business we're writing to given policy year, and that new business that we write in that term. That comes on at a higher loss ratio early, and then as we revenue, it improves. If you look at the production such as that we've been disclosing and the high levels of new business, what's happening inside the portfolio then, which is the second piece is on average, the portfolio is getting younger, right. And if younger business carries a higher loss ratio, that's what we described as the increase in the combined. So when you look at the outlook for the first half of -- I'm sorry, the second of '16, we see the combined ratio will be higher due to the impact of the higher new business we have been writing. That is the underlying dynamic that's flowing through the book. That does conclude the Mac in the first half of '17, it just gets offset by an expectation of return to normalized non-cat weather levels. And so, the underlying dynamic of the book getting younger, meaning less tenure, right, we've had the accounts not as long, continued into '17, recognize also though that as we write more Quantum Auto 2.0 business, there is a benefit for the combined ratio from an offsetting improvement in the expense ratio, because it carries a commission. So that underlying aging of the book or reducing average tenure of the book, does continue into '17. It just gets offset by again an expectation of return to more normalized weather, that's why the outlook attention, not an expectation.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's assumption, sorry.
componenttext: It's assumption, sorry.

We clearly expect that hitting the expectations of retaining the business is important, which is why, in my comments, I emphasized that as they're going into the year 2 and in some cases the year 3 of the Quantum Auto 2.0 product, we feel really good that we are hitting the retention rates we expected. So whatever our expectation was for life expectancy, along with our statement about losses are progressing, so is the retention of the business. And you can look at our long-term retention and begin to deduce some kind of policy life expectancy by just doing a

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get a bit more insight on the share buybacks. It's slowed over the past few quarters on a linked quarter basis. And the slow down in share buybacks was actually a little greater than the reduction in earnings in the first half of '15 to th
componenttext: I was hoping to get a bit more insight on the share buybacks. It's slowed over the past few quarters on a linked quarter basis. And the slow down in share buybacks was actually a little greater than the reduction in earnings in the first half of '15 to the first half of '16. Can you give us a bit more insight on that?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jay, this is Jack. I think you're looking back at a period of time and we have said in the past, over time, share buyback is going to be enabled by earnings. And while this pension contributions and whatever, is the earnings of the place over time, that w
componenttext: Jay, this is Jack. I think you're looking back at a period of time and we have said in the past, over time, share buyback is going to be enabled by earnings. And while this pension contributions and whatever, is the earnings of the place over time, that will drive what the total share buybacks and dividends are. And what you saw, and I think you've even asked the question in the past, can we continue to buy back at levels that are higher than our earnings. Well, this is the flipside of it, this is just an indication of the timing element of when we look and see what the future quarter projections are. They obviously come out to be whatever they'll be. And we'll just take the numbers in the particular quarter that we're doing a share buyback. So for a longer-term, view to say, in this particular quarter, 550 sounds like the right number. So I wouldn't read anything into it in terms of the change in philosophy or a change in execution. It's just going to be as we refer to a normal quarterly variation in a policy and a discipline that's been set for a long period of time.

componenttext: Sure, in terms of Brexit, the most significant impact to us would be whatever it means for overall economic activity. The amount of premium that we write out of the U.K. that relies on is very, very small. It's something like 5% of our overall international premium and about half of that is and we assume that we are in another. Lloyd's will address the part, but as we will by the way. Long way to go to see how that's going to work out and what the ultimate arrangements are going to be, but other than the overall macro impact, we don't extent any significant impact to us.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask about the competitive landscape in the Personal Lines business. We've had a few management changes progressive and state forward. I'm wondering if the components on crew has been competitive out there, have changed in the last year?
componenttext: I want to ask about the competitive landscape in the Personal Lines business. We've had a few management changes progressive and state forward. I'm wondering if the components on crew has been competitive out there, have changed in the last year?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Michael Klein. I would say, broadly speaking to answer that question is, no. I mean, competitive dynamics are very local in the business as well. And so while there have been changes in management from national competitors, and frankly some
componenttext: Paul, this is Michael Klein. I would say, broadly speaking to answer that question is, no. I mean, competitive dynamics are very local in the business as well. And so while there have been changes in management from national competitors, and frankly some local, regional as well. The broad competitive dynamics of the business remain consistent when we look at the rate filing monitoring that we do in the business to assess the rates your taken in particular states in Auto or Home, we don't see a lot of shift in behavior there. So I would say the competitive dynamics are broadly consistent.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The general idea is that the agency books keep losing share. And regional and the direct people are the most competitive, is that still the case?
componenttext: The general idea is that the agency books keep losing share. And regional and the direct people are the most competitive, is that still the case?

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at the latest you'll continue to see some incremental shift in share by channel. Interestingly, I think, consistent with the last couple of years, a majority of the gains are being in sort of online direction or as they're coming from
componenttext: I think if you look at the latest you'll continue to see some incremental shift in share by channel. Interestingly, I think, consistent with the last couple of years, a majority of the gains are being in sort of online direction or as they're coming from and less and less from independent agency. But broadly, I think those trends continue.

headline: The Travelers Companies, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay Benet. Somebody asked the question about what was the impact on the combined ratio of non-cat weather. And let me -- I will give you the number. But I also have to give you a little bit of the preference to it. We are passing things very thin
componenttext: This is Jay Benet. Somebody asked the question about what was the impact on the combined ratio of non-cat weather. And let me -- I will give you the number. But I also have to give you a little bit of the preference to it. We are passing things very thin here and talking strictly about that. So if you asked the question what's the impact of non-cat weather on the combined ratio on a consolidated basis, we would say it's 150 basis points. But I'd also point out that if you asked the question about well, what about other losses, that goes in a different direction. And what about mix? And that goes in a different direction. So we will answer your question, but there is lots and lots of things that are taking place here, that make the 1 number, not necessarily indicative of the trends or what's going to -- what the expectation is. So I'd just urge you to go back to a queue and the outlook to see what to us actually translates into.
